certain forms of these animals in their living state, that their
true place in the animal kingdom is among the <u>Bryozoa</u>. [<u>Note</u> See his memoirs in the Transactions of the Royal Academy of Berlin, for 
1839 and 1840; also Taylor's Scientific Memoirs, Vol III,p.319.] He
describes them as possessing a distinct alimentary canal, which
extends from segment to segment; this however, instead of
being single, <s>(</s> as in Nonionina, may (he tells us) be multiple, as
in <u>Geophonus</u>; so that we must regard each segment of the latter,
however apparently resembling the simple segment of the former,
is in reality composed of several adhering bodies. In one
instance (he affirms) he found the mouth surrounded by a
plumose sensory and prehensile apparatus, like that of the
[Hust?] and Halcyonella (see [section?], <s>p</s> §4) but generally speaking
he admits that this is altogether wanting, the mouth being a
simple aperture. He <s>said</s> saw minute extensile tentacula <s>proceeding</s> proceeding
from all parts of the seive-like shell, as described by Dujardin,
and admitted their resemblance to the pseudopodia of <u>Difflugia</u>
[?] but he remarks "the rest of their organisation, which Dujardin
has overlooked, removes them from the Infusoria quite, as far as
